reviewText: I have always enjoyed the novels of Graham Hurley and had wished they would be made into a UK TV series.  It is somewhat strange seeing them moved to Le Havre and the characters moved as well, given very similar names.  Although competently made, the series lacks a little spark, possibly because the script and the characters try too hard to stick closely to events/people which could only really happen in England.I doubt whether ratings will be spectacular for this series, which I would summarize with that terrible word: "Average"
Title: Blood on the Docks: Volume 1

reviewText: Loved this series wish they had moreGreat character acting interest story line and plot well acted

Title: Blood on the Docks: Volume 1

reviewText: The French crime drama "Blood on the Docks" is really a series of TV movies from 2011 and 2012.  Each episode runs approximately ninety minutes and has a primary self-contained investigation.  As you might expect, certain plot points are continued between episodes as the series expertly paints the portrait of a city descending into a criminal chaos. With so many crime procedurals on TV today, it becomes increasingly difficult to find ones that bring something special to the mix. Truthfully, don't you feel like you've seen every possible crime, every possible culprit, and every possible plot twist under the sun? I know I do! But, I must admit, I still love the good ones. Whether a grizzled police veteran, a cunning private eye, or a new breed of truth seeker, you can always count on the protagonist to peel away the layers of a twisty investigation to arrive at a stunning revelation! Despite the overabundance of these shows, I will say that I still enjoyed "Blood on the Docks" for the vivid atmosphere it creates."Blood on the Docks" even employs one of the oldest cliches in the book.  Pairing two mismatched cops, one is an ambitious by-the-books investigator and one is a wily veteran who isn't afraid to color outside of the lines.  Sounds awfully familiar, doesn't it?  Add a savvy tech nerd, a rookie new to the beat, and an unscrupulous boss who only cares about covering her own assets (if you know what I mean) and you've got the standard set-up you've seen dozens (if not more) times before.  I don't mean to be harsh, though, because the show still works.  Why?  Lead actors Jean-Marc Barr and Bruno Solo have a terrific chemistry and play off one another expertly.  There is some good personal stuff involving Barr's son (a fascinating character) and Solo's ties to the community he is sworn to protect.  I also enjoyed the depiction of Le Havre, the northern port town where the action is set.All of the individual stories were adapted from English writer Graham Hurley's DI Joe Faraday series of which there have been twelve entries so far.  Normally, I would include a brief teaser with each chapter, but the product description has already provided a comprehensive plot synopsis.Included in this set:Angels Passing (2011)  Based on the third novel in the seriesCut To Black (2011)  Based on the fifth novel in the series.One Under (2012)  Based on the seventh novel in the series.Blood and Honey (2012)  Based on the sixth novel in the series.Two additional movies were made in 2013 that are not in this volume.  So if you enjoy these, keep your eyes peeled for the next DVD installment.  KGHarris, 12/13.
summary: Great Chemistry By The Leads Distinguish This Otherwise Fairly Conventional French Crime Procedural
Title: Blood on the Docks: Volume 1
